questions.text: Where does one find flat non-ciliated epithelium in the middle ear cleft?
questions.solution:
The flat non-ciliated epithelium is found in the mastoid air cells and the epitympanum.

The mucosal lining of the middle ear is continuous with that of the nasopharynx but shows variations:

  • Bony eustachian tube- ciliated columnar
  • Cartilaginous eustachian tube- ciliated pseudostratified columnar
  • Protympanum- ciliated columnar
  • Most of the middle ear space- cuboidal
  • Epitympanum & mastoid air cells- flat non-ciliated.

questions.text: Which is the largest mastoid air cell?
questions.solution:
The mastoid antrum is the largest mastoid air cell.

It is the most constant mastoid air cell because it is present even in a sclerotic mastoid.

The attic or the epitympanum is the part of the middle ear adjacent to its roof.

Aditus ad antrum is the pathway or the connection between mastoid antrum and attic.

questions.text: A patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis undergoes cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum?
questions.solution: Macewen’s (suprameatal) triangle is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. In an adult, the antrum lies 12–15 mm from the surface. This triangle is also the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of the suprameatal triangle?

choices.text: Posterosuperior segment of bony external auditory canal
Tangent drawn to external auditory canal

questions.solution:
Promontory does not form the boundary of the suprameatal triangle.

Boundaries of MacEwen’s (suprameatal) triangle:

  • Superior- temporal line
  • Anterior-  posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal
  • Posterior- the line drawn as a tangent to the external canal.

It is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery.

Image showing the suprameatal triangle:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
The mandible is not a pneumatic bone.

Some bones of the skull, notably the mastoid process of the temporal bone and the paranasal sinuses of the frontal, maxilla, sphenoid and ethmoid bones, many of the internal cavities are filled with air, i.e. they are variably pneumatized.

The maxillae are the largest of the pneumatized bones of the midface. They contain the maxillary air sinuses and bear the upper teeth.

The mastoid consists of a bone cortex with a 'honeycomb' of air cells underneath.

questions.text: You are evaluating a patient with past history of chronic suppurative otitis media. The CT is suggestive of sclerosis and loss of aeration of mastoid air cells. What is this type of mastoid pneumatization called?
questions.solution:
The type of mastoid pneumatization in the given clinical scenario is acellular or sclerotic mastoid.

Here, sclerosis and loss of aeration of mastoid air cells are seen. Sclerotic mastoids contain only mastoid antrum which is small with anteposed sigmoid sinus. It can occur due to eustachian or middle ear disease in childhood preventing mastoid development.

Other types of mastoids pneumatization:

  • Well-pneumatized or cellular- contains multiple air spaces
  • Diploetic- contains air cells and marrow spaces.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the temporal bone?
questions.solution:
The parietal is not a part of the temporal bone.

The temporal bone consists of the following parts:

Squamous part- anterosuperiorly

It articulates with the parietal bone. The persistence of petrosquamous suture is called Korner's septum.

Mastoid part- posteroinferiorly. 

Its outer surface forms a conical projection called the mastoid process. Sternocleidomastoid, splenius capitis and longissimus capitis attach here.

Petrous part- medially

  • The arcuate eminence is related to the superior semicircular canal below
  • The posterior surface contains the internal auditory meatus (IAM). The vestibular aqueduct is present behind the IAM.
  • The inferior surface contains the carotid canal and the jugular fossa (jugular notch). 

Tympanic part- centrally

  • It contains the external auditory meatus (EAM), and the bony EAM is 16 mm long.
  • The suprameatal triangle is present above the EAM

Styloid process- anteroinferior

it gives attachment to:

  • 3 muscles - stylohyoid, styloglossus, stylopharyngeus
  • 2 ligaments - stylohyoid ligament, stylomandibular ligament

Zygomatic process

The temporal bone gives the zygomatic process which articulates with the temporal process of the zygomatic bone to form the zygomatic arch.

questions.text: While performing cortical mastoidectomy, the head and neck surgeon drills the bone up to the Citelli's angle. This angle is seen between which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Citelli’s angle or sinodural angle is the angle between the sigmoid sinus plate and tegmen or dural plate. 

The boundaries of cortical mastoidectomy are:

  • Tegmen plate superiorly
  • Sigmoid sinus plate posteriorly
  • Posterior bony external auditory canal wall anteriorly

This is also called the triangle of attack.

Image showing sinodural angle:

questions.text: Endolymphatic sac surgery is performed on a patient who has Ménière disease with intractable vertigo. Which of the following is the surgical landmark to identify the sac?
questions.solution:
Donaldson’s line is the surgical landmark to locate the endolymphatic sac.

It is an imaginary line drawn from the horizontal semicircular canal, which bisects the posterior semicircular canal. The endolymphatic sac lies just below it. 

Image showing Donaldson’s line:

ELS: Endolymphatic sac; HSCC: Horizontal semicircular canal, PSCC: Posterior semicircular canal; PF dura: Posterior fossa dura.

questions.text: A head and neck surgeon enters the cranial cavity via the Trautmann’s triangle. Which fossa can be approached through this triangle?
questions.solution:
Trautmann’s triangle is a landmark to approach the posterior cranial fossa.

  • It is a triangular area on the medial wall of the mastoid antrum.
  • It is bounded superiorly by the dura or superior petrosal sinus, posteriorly by the sigmoid sinus, and anteriorly by the bony labyrinth.
  • Since here the bone is thin, it can lead to the spreading of infections from the mastoid to the cerebellum.

Image showing the Trautmann’s triangle:
